user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TaskGetInfo(osal_id_t task_id, OS_task_prop_t *task_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *       record;
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_prop);

    memset(task_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_task_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_task_table, token);
        task   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            strncpy(task_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(task_prop->name) - 1);
            task_prop->name[sizeof(task_prop->name) - 1] = 0;
        }
        task_prop->creator    = record->creator;
        task_prop->stack_size = task->stack_size;
        task_prop->priority   = task->priority;

        return_code = OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl(&token, task_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_task_table
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char            task_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
    osal_task_entry entry_function_pointer;
    osal_task_entry delete_hook_pointer;
    void *          entry_arg;
    osal_stackptr_t stack_pointer;
} OS_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char            name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t       creator;
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
} OS_task_prop_t
...
int32 OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_task_prop_t *task_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected all executable statements and the main success-path block in OS_TaskGetInfo because unreachable-code concerns arise where execution may be prevented by non-returning macros/functions (e.g. BUGCHECK via OS_CHECK_POINTER), by functions that may never return a success path, or by mismatched token/transaction handling that could make later lines effectively unreachable. Declarations (function signature and local variable declarations) and simple type/structure definitions are not included because they are not executable code and thus cannot be 'unreachable' in the sense of Rule 2.1. Helper definitions shown (OS_SUCCESS, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl as provided returning OS_SUCCESS, OS_ObjectIdRelease wrapper) are also not flagged further here because either they are non-executable macros/definitions or trivially-returning functions in the provided code; the primary risk areas for unreachable execution are the checks, the object-id acquisition call, and the conditional success block (including the call to the implementation and the release), so those were reported for further investigation.
